Graphical abstract The effect of Ni substitution on the Fischer–Tropsch (FT) synthesis activity and selectivity of alumina supported cobalt (Co/Al2O3) catalyst was investigated with a continuous stirred tank reactor at 230°C and 1MPa. Bimetallic Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. Total amount of supported metal was fixed at 20wt%. Influence of the Co/Ni ratio, impregnation sequences and solutions on the structure and activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was systematically studied. Low Ni-loading slightly increased CO conversion rate at nearly constant C5+ selectivity, but excess Ni-loading largely decreased CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity. The catalytic activity did not depend on impregnation sequence, when Ni-loading amount was low. However, when Co was substituted with large amount of Ni, catalysts prepared by sequential impregnation method (Ni first and then Co) showed higher activity than those prepared by co-impregnation method and reverse sequential impregnation method (Co first and then Ni). These results indicate that catalysts with a Co-rich surface would be better than those with a Ni-rich surface. Impregnation solution also influenced the catalytic activity. Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method using aqueous NH3 solution (Co+Ni/Al2O3-A) showed higher activity than those prepared using pure water or aqueous HNO3 solution. The best catalyst was Co(19wt%)+Ni(1wt%)/Al2O3-A, which exhibited 1.6 times as high activity as Co(20wt%)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method. The variation of catalytic activity with the kind of impregnation solution would be attributed to the differences in CO adsorption amount and/or electron density of surface Co metal sites. Keywords Fischer–Tropsch synthesis Bimetallic catalyst Cobalt Nickel Alumina 1 Introduction In recent years, it is highly desired to establish the practical method of producing clean alternative fuels from the aspects of environmental preservation and energy security. FT synthesis is considered as one of the promising ways to produce liquid fuels, because hydrocarbon mixtures can be produced from various carbon sources (e.g., coal, natural gas and biomass) via syngas [1,2]. Furthermore, environmentally benign liquid fuels without containing any sulfur, nitrogen and aromatic compounds can be obtained by FT synthesis. Thus, FT synthesis has attracted renewed attentions. Various examinations such as the improvement of catalysts and reactors are currently carried out to enhance the efficiency of this reaction system. Potential catalysts for FT synthesis are some transition metals such as Fe, Co, Ru and Ni. Among them, Co-based catalysts are advantageous to the practical application due to the relatively high activity and selectivity to long-chain linear hydrocarbons, high resistance toward deactivation, low activity for the competitive water-gas shift reaction and lower price than Ru [3–5]. It had been accepted that FT synthesis over Co catalyst would be a structure-insensitive reaction, and activity of Co catalyst would depend on the number of exposed Co metal sites on the catalyst surface [6–8]. Therefore, Co was typically deposited on supports having high surface area (e.g., SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2 and carbon materials) in order to increase the number of active Co metal sites [1–5]. However, several research groups recently reported that turnover frequency (TOF) monotonically decreased with decreasing Co particle size when Co particle size was smaller than ca. 10nm [9–11]. These reports mean that the optimum Co particle size would exist for Co-based FT catalysts. Therefore, the precise control of Co particle size is very important for the development of highly active Co catalysts for FT synthesis. The type of support material is another important factor to determine the activity of Co catalyst for FT synthesis. Alumina (Al2O3) is frequently employed as support for Co-based FT catalyst due to the high thermal stability and the strong resistance to attrition. Al2O3 support may be also effective for the extension of catalyst lifetime, since high ability of Al2O3 support to stabilize small metal clusters would suppress the aggregation of Co metal particles during catalytic reaction. However, the strong interaction between Al2O3 support and Co oxide particles suppresses the reduction of Co oxide at the same time. This means a decrease in the number of active Co metal sites and leads to the formation of low active catalysts. Thus, small amount of noble metals (e.g., Pt [12–14], Re [12,13,15], Ru [12,13,16], Pd [13,17], Ir [18], Au [19,20] and Ag [19,21]) is often added to Co/Al2O3 catalysts, since they can facilitate the reduction of Co oxide and increase the number of active Co metal sites, presumably by hydrogen dissociation and spillover from the promoter surface. However, noble metals are not suitable to the industrial application due to their high cost. Nowadays, elements other than noble metal, such as Zr [22], alkali earth elements [23], rare earth elements [24], and others [25–27], are examined as the reduction promoter. Other methods, such as improvement in the preparation method of Co/Al2O3 catalysts [28–33] and structural control of Al2O3 support [34–39], are also studied in order to improve the Co reducibility of Co/Al2O3 catalysts. Bimetallic catalysts such as Co–Fe and Co–Ru are often reported to show high activity for FT synthesis [40]. Substitution of cheap metals for Co is also effective for the lowering of catalyst price. Although Ni is active for FT synthesis, the formation of short-chain hydrocarbons, especially methane, is usually predominant over Ni catalyst due to having a high hydrogenation ability [5]. However, Ishihara and coworkers reported that bimetallic Co–Ni catalysts showed high activity for FT synthesis [41–43]. They systematically studied the support effect of bimetallic Co–Ni catalyst and succeeded in the preparation of Co–Ni catalyst showing high activity and selectivity to gasoline-range hydrocarbons (C5–C12). It was also reported that Ni was effective as the reduction promoter of supported Co catalysts such as Co/SiO2 [44], Co/Al2O3 [45], Co/HZSM-5 [46] and Co/CNT [47]. Although various attempts have been made to prepare highly active bimetallic Co–Ni catalyst for FT synthesis, factors influencing the activity of Co–Ni catalyst are not fully understood yet. In the present study, Al2O3 supported bimetallic Co–Ni (Co–Ni/Al2O3) catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. The activity of prepared Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts for FT synthesis was investigated with a continuous stirred tank reactor. The effect of Co/Ni ratio, impregnation sequences and solutions on the structure and activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was studied in detail. We found that Co(19)+Ni(1)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a co-impregnation method using aqueous NH3 solution exhibited 1.6 times higher activity than Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method. We systematically examined relationships between the structure of active metal sites and the activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst in order to obtain the catalyst design concept. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by three methods, i.e., co-impregnation, sequential impregnation and reverse sequential impregnation methods. Starting materials employed are Co(NO3)2∙6H2O (99.5%, Wako), Ni(NO3)2∙6H2O (99.9%, Wako) and θ-Al2O3 (BET specific surface area: 84m2 g−1). θ-Al2O3 was obtained by the calcination of commercial boehmite (AlO(OH)∙nH2O, Wako) in air at 1000°C for 10h, followed by washing with distilled water and drying at 100°C [48]. Total amount of supported metal was fixed at 20wt% for all samples. In the co-impregnation method, Al2O3 powder (8.0g) was dispersed into an aqueous solution (100ml) of metal precursor and stirred for 0.5h, followed by evaporation to dryness at 90°C. Then, the obtained powder was dried at 100°C for 12h and calcined in air at 400°C for 3h. In the sequential impregnation method, Ni was loaded by the impregnation method, followed by drying at 100°C and calcination in air at 400°C for 3h. Then, Co was loaded on Ni/Al2O3 catalyst by the impregnation method, followed by drying at 100°C and calcination in air at 400°C for 3h. In the reverse sequential impregnation method, catalysts were prepared using the same procedure as sequential impregnation method. However, Co was impregnated in the first step and Ni was impregnated in the second step. The catalysts prepared by co-impregnation, sequential impregnation and reverse sequential impregnation methods are referred to as Co(x)+Ni(y)/Al2O3, Co(x)/Ni(y)/Al2O3 and Ni(y)/Co(x)/Al2O3, where x and y show the loading amount of Co and Ni, respectively. Some Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the co-impregnation method using aqueous solutions of HNO3 (1molL−1, Wako) or NH3 (28%, Nacalai Tesque). The former catalyst was referred to as Co+Ni/Al2O–N and the latter was Co+Ni/Al2O3-A. Preparation procedure of Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts was same as that of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. However, aqueous solutions of HNO3 (1ml) or NH3 (5ml) were added to the impregnation solution. The pH of the impregnation solution was ca. 3 for Co+Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst and ca. 9 for Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst, respectively. 2.2 Characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was measured at room temperature with a Rigaku diffractometer RINT 2500 TTRIII using Cu Kα radiation (50kV, 300mA). The mean particle size of Co3O4 (d Co3O4) was calculated from the diffraction line at 2θ =36.9 degree with the Scherrer equation. The particle size of NiO was calculated from the diffraction line at 2θ =43.3 degree. The obtained particle size of Co3O4 was used to calculate that of Co metal (d Co) after hydrogen reduction pretreatment by the following formula (Eq. (1)) [14]. (1) d Co = 0.75 × d C O 3 O 4 Temperature programmed reduction under H2 (H2-TPR) was carried out with BELCAT-B (BEL Japan Inc.). The calcined catalyst (0.10g) was mounted in a quartz cell and heated up to 900°C in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (30mlmin−1). The heating rate was 10°Cmin−1. The reduction degree of supported metal was calculated from the amount of H2 consumption during H2 reduction pretreatment at 400°C for 6h, assuming that Co and Ni were deposited as Co3O4 and NiO, respectively, before the reduction pretreatment. The effluent gas was passed through a 5A molecular sieve trap to remove the produced water before reaching a thermal conductivity detector. Hydrogen chemisorption experiments were performed with BELCAT-B. Before the measurement, samples (0.05–0.10g) were reduced at 400°C for 6h in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (15mlmin−1) and held at 400°C for 1h in a flow of Ar (30mlmin−1) to desorb the residual chemisorbed hydrogen. After cooling the sample down to 100°C in a flow of Ar, H2 chemisorption measurements were started. Dispersion was calculated based on the total number of supported metal. In situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were recorded with a JASCO FT/IR-4100 spectrometer equipped with a diffuse reflectance attachment and a MCT detector. The sample was placed in an infrared cell equipped with CaF2 windows. The spectra were obtained by collecting 64 scans at 4cm−1 resolution. Before the measurement, samples were reduced at 450°C for 4h in a flow of 5% H2/Ar (40mlmin−1) and held at 450°C for 0.5h in a flow of N2 (40mlmin−1) to desorb the residual chemisorbed hydrogen. Subsequently, the system was cooled down to 30°C in a flow of N2 and a background spectrum was recorded. Next, 10% CO/He (40mlmn−1) was fed to the cell for 5min. After adsorption of CO, the IR cell was purged with N2 to remove gaseous CO and then IR spectra were recorded. 2.3 Typical procedures of catalytic reactions FT synthesis was performed with a continuous stirred tank reactor in a similar way to the previous study [49]. Before the reaction, catalyst (1.5–2.0g) was in-situ reduced in a flow of H2 (40ml min−1) at 400°C for 6h. After the reactor was cooled down to room temperature and purged with N2 gas, n-hexadecane solvent (80g) was added to the reactor. Then, the reaction was carried out at 230°C and 1.0MPa for 8h in a flow of synthetic gas (110mlmin−1). The syngas used for the present study was obtained by gasification of woody biomass, followed by gas purification and composition adjustment [50]. Since the syngas obtained by gasification of woody biomass contained impurities such as sulfur and tarry compounds, they were removed by passing the gas through scrubber and desulfurization tower [50,51]. After gas cleaning, the concentration of sulfur compounds decreased to less than 5ppb [51]. Composition of this biomass-derived syngas was confirmed by gas chromatography (GC) as follows: H2 (60.0%), CO (31.3%), CH4 (4.7%) and N2 (4.0%). The effluent gas after FT synthesis was analyzed by on-line GC. A thermal conductivity detector (TCD) with a Porapak-Q column was used to analyze inorganic gases (H2, CO, CO2, CH4 and N2). Light hydrocarbons (C1 C4) were analyzed by a flame ionization detector (FID) with a RT-QPLOT capillary column. Hydrocarbons dissolved in the solvent and cooled in a trap were analyzed by GC-FID equipped with a UA-DX30 capillary column. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared in different impregnation sequences Co-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared in different impregnation sequences, i.e., co-impregnation, sequential impregnation and reverse sequential impregnation methods, were analyzed by XRD, H2-TPR and H2-chemisorption. Figs. 1–3 (A) show XRD patterns of Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts before H2 reduction pretreatment. From XRD pattern of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst, peaks assigned to θ-Al2O3 and Co3O4 were observed. Peaks of other Co compounds (e.g., CoO and Co aluminate) were not observed from the spectrum of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. XRD pattern of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst contained peaks assigned to θ-Al2O3 and NiO. XRD patterns of Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts were composed from the mixture of θ-Al2O3 and Co3O4, although small diffraction lines assigned to NiO were also observed from the spectrum of Ni(10)/Co(10)/Al2O3 catalyst. Disappearance of NiO peaks from the spectra of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts indicates that Ni species would be highly dispersed on Al2O3 support. Particle sizes of Co3O4 and Co metal were calculated from the diffraction line at 36.9 degree using the Scherrer Eq. (1). The results were listed in Table 1 . The particle sizes of Co3O4 and Co metal on Co(20)/Al2O3 catalysts were 20.2 and 15.2nm, respectively. Co3O4 particle sizes of Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts were 16.1–18.6, 13.8–19.3 and 14.8–19.8nm, respectively. The particle sizes of Co metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts were 12.1–13.9, 10.3–14.5 and 11.1–14.9nm, respectively. As Ni-loading amount increased, Co3O4 particle size of Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts monotonically decreased (Fig. 4 (A)). However, Co3O4 particle size of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts first decreased with increasing Ni-loading amount until 5wt% and then became constant. These results show that dispersion of Co3O4 particles would depend on the impregnation sequence. Figs. 1–3(B) show H2-TPR profiles of Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts. The spectrum of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst showed that reduction of Co species on Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst began around 250°C and all Co species were completely reduced at 800°C. It is generally accepted that peak observed at 300–400°C corresponds to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO and peaks at 400–600°C correspond to the reduction of CoO to Co metal [3]. Similarly, peaks observed at more than 600°C are originated from the reduction of barely reducible Co species such as cobalt aluminate. The spectrum of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst also showed that the reduction of Ni species on Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst began around 330°C and all Ni species were completely reduced at 850°C. H2-TPR profiles of bimetallic Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts largely depended on the impregnation sequence. When Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by the co-impregnation method, low temperature peak around 350°C shifted to lower temperature with increasing Ni-loading amount (Fig. 1(B)). Furthermore, increase in Ni-loading amount largely decreased the area of high temperature peaks more than 600°C. These results indicate that Ni-loading increases the Co reducibility when Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts are prepared by the co-impregnation method. H2-TPR profiles of Co/Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were shown in Fig. 2(B). As in the case of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst, peak assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO shifted to lower temperature with increasing Ni-loading amount. However, Ni-loading amount had a small influence on the area of high temperature peak more than 600°C, indicating that Ni-loading would not promote the reduction of Co oxide to Co metal over Co/Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. In the case of Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 3(B)), Ni-loading did not change the position of low temperature peak, although the area of high temperature peaks more than 600°C tended to decrease with increasing Ni-loading amount. These results clearly show that reduction property of Co3O4 particles would largely vary with the impregnation sequence. Reduction degree and dispersion of supported metal were listed in Table 1. Co reduction degree of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was 63% and Ni reduction degree of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was 70%. Reduction degrees of supported metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts were 70–82%, 54–63% and 54–66%, respectively. Over Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, reduction degree monotonically increased with increasing Ni-loading amount (Fig. 4(B)). In contrast, reduction degree of Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts was smaller than that of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst, when Ni-loading amount was 1–5wt%. Comparing the catalysts with the same Co/Ni ratio, reduction degree of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was much higher than that of Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts. Dispersion of supported metal also depended on the impregnation sequence. Co dispersion of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was 0.83% and Ni dispersion of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was 2.95% (Table 1, entries 1, 5). Dispersion of supported metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3, Co/Ni/Al2O3 and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalysts was 1.23–2.19%, 0.91–2.02% and 0.85–1.73%, respectively. As Ni-loading amount increased, dispersion of supported metal monotonically increased for all series of samples (Fig. 4(C)). When catalysts with the same Co/Ni ratio were compared, Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed the highest dispersion, and Ni/Co/Al2O3 catalyst showed the lowest one. Dispersion of Co/Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was the value intermediate between the former two samples. As a conclusion of this section, impregnation sequence and Ni-loading amount largely influenced the Co3O4 particle size, reduction degree and dispersion of supported metal. Co3O4 particle size decreased and dispersion of supported metal increased with increasing Ni-loading amount. When catalysts with the same Co/Ni ratio were compared, catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method showed higher reduction degree and dispersion than those prepared by sequential impregnation and reverse sequential impregnation methods. 3.2 Characterization of Co-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared using different impregnation solutions Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, which were prepared by the co-impregnation method using aqueous solutions of HNO3 or NH3, were characterized by XRD, H2-TPR and H2-chemisorption. Figs. 5 and 6 (A) show XRD patterns of Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts. As in the case of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 1(A)), peaks assigned to Co3O4 and θ-Al2O3 were observed from the XRD patterns of Co(20)/Al2O3-N, Co+Ni/Al2O3-N, Co(20)/Al2O3-A and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts, while peaks of NiO and θ-Al2O3 were observed from the spectra of Ni(20)/Al2O3-N and Ni(20)/Al2O3-A catalysts. Co3O4 particle size measured by XRD was 16.2–18.8nm for Co+Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst and 13.2–14.9nm for Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst (Table 1, entries 12–21). The particle sizes of Co metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts were 12.2–14.1 and 9.9–11.2nm, respectively. As shown in Fig. 7 (A), Co3O4 particle size tended to decrease with increasing Ni-loading amount. H2-TPR profiles of Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts were shown in Figs. 5 and 6(B). As in the case of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts (Fig. 1(B)), peak assigned to the reduction of Co3O4 to CoO (ca. 350°C) shifted to lower temperature with increasing the Ni-loading amount. Increase in the Ni-loading amount also decreased the area of high temperature peaks more than 600°C. However, compared with Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 1(B)), fraction of high temperature peaks above 600°C was much larger over Co+Ni/Al2O3-N (Fig. 5(B)) and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A (Fig. 6(B)) catalysts. Especially, large reduction peak was observed at 750°C from the spectra of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts. Low Co reducibility of Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts is attributed to the fact that metal-support interaction would be strengthened by using aqueous solutions of HNO3 or NH3 as the impregnation solution. Bae et al. reported the effect of pH of the impregnation solution on the structure of Co/Al2O3 catalyst [29]. They proposed that in an acidic solution, electric repulsion between positively charged Al2O3 surface and Co2+ ion would induce the formation of inhomogeneous Co3O4 particles with various sizes. Thus, parts of small Co3O4 particles would interact strongly with Al2O3 support and decrease the Co reducibility of Co/Al2O3 catalyst. On the other hand, in an alkali solution, Co precursor should be loaded partly by deposition and precipitation, which would induce strong metal-support interaction, decrease the size of Co3O4 particles and lead to the formation of Co/Al2O3 catalyst with low Co reducibility. Reduction degree and dispersion of supported metal were also investigated for Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts. Results were listed in Table 1, entries 12–21. Reduction degrees of supported metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts were 49–76% and 40–66%, respectively. As expected from the results of H2-TPR (Figs. 5 and 6(B)), reduction degree tended to increase with increasing Ni-loading amount for both series of samples (Fig. 7(B)). Dispersion of supported metal on Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts was 0.69–3.27% and 0.58–3.51%, respectively, and it also increased with increasing Ni-loading amount (Fig. 7(C)). Influence of impregnation solution on Co3O4 particle size, reduction degree and dispersion was discussed in more detail. Comparing the catalysts with the same Co/Ni ratio, Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst showed the largest Co3O4 particle size and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst showed the smallest one (Fig. 7(A)). Co3O4 particle size of Co+Ni/Al2O3-N catalyst was the value intermediate between the former two samples, when Ni-loading amount was 0–1wt%. Large Co3O4 particle size of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is due to the weak metal-support interaction, while small Co3O4 particle size of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst is attributed to the strong metal-support interaction. The reduction degree and dispersion decreased in the same order, i.e., Co+Ni/Al2O3 >Co+Ni/Al2O3-N>Co+Ni/Al2O3-A (Fig. 7(B) and (C)). The differences in reduction degree and dispersion among three kinds of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts can be also explained by the strength of metal-support interaction. In other words, low reduction degree and dispersion of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts would be attributed to the strongest metal-support reaction, since strong metal-support interaction would promote the formation of hardly reducible Co species (e.g., cobalt aluminate) and suppress the formation of Co metal sites by the reduction pretreatment. On the other hand, high reduction degree and dispersion of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts are probably due to the weakest metal-support interaction, which would increase the Co reducibility and promote the formation of Co metal sites by the reduction pretreatment. As a conclusion of this section, structural factors of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts, such as Co3O4 particle size, reduction degree and dispersion of supported metal, were largely varied with the kind of impregnation solution. When NH3 aqueous solution was used as the impregnation solution, Co3O4 particle size, reduction degree and dispersion of supported metal were smaller than those of catalysts prepared using other impregnation solutions. 3.3 Catalytic performance of various Co-Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and structure-activity relationship FT synthesis was performed on various Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts using a continuous stirred tank reactor at 230°C and 1.0MPa for 8h. Fig. 8 shows time course of CO conversion over Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts as the representative. CO conversion over Ni(20)/Al2O3-A catalyst monotonically decreased with increasing reaction time. However, activity of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts expect for Ni(20)/Al2O3-A was almost constant within the examined reaction time. The same tendency was observed over other Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared using different impregnation sequences and solutions. In other words, rapid deactivation was observed over catalysts containing Ni only, while stable activity was obtained over catalysts containing Co. However, it is expected that activity of all Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts will gradually decrease with increasing reaction time due to the structural changes of active sites, such as sintering, surface reconstruction and carbide formation, as reported by various research groups [52,53]. Therefore, in this paper, we only discussed the initial catalytic activity (8h after the reaction started), since we did not carry out the long time reaction tests. We will examine the lifetime of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts and report in the near future. However, it should be noted that in our previous study using similar reaction condition and reaction setup, the activity of Co/SiO2 and Co/Mn+Zr/SiO2 catalysts was almost constant for 1 week owing to the precise control of reaction temperature and the use of hexadecane solvent [54]. Thus, we expect that deactivation of the Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts may be quite slow in the present reaction condition and reaction setup. Table 2 shows CO conversion, product selectivity, CO conversion rate and TOF over various Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts. TOF was calculated from CO conversion rate and metal dispersion determined by H2 chemisorption. First, the activity of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was compared with that of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. CO conversion rate, CH4 selectivity, C5+ selectivity and TOF of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst were 24.6mmolg−1 h−1, 9%, 80% and 0.21s−1, respectively (Table 2, entry 1). CO conversion rate, CH4 selectivity, C5+ selectivity and TOF of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst were 16.5mmolg−1 h−1, 23%, 43% and 0.05s−1, respectively (Table 2, entry 5). CO conversion rate, C5+ selectivity and TOF of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst were much lower than those of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. CH4 selectivity of Ni(20)/Al2O3 catalyst was much higher than that of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. These results are consistent with the general trend that Ni catalyst preferentially produces short-chain hydrocarbons and Co catalyst is effective for the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons. Next, activities of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared in different impregnation sequences were compared. CO conversion rate, C5+ selectivity and TOF were plotted against Ni-loading amount (Fig. 9 ). When Ni-loading amount was 1wt%, CO conversion rate was slightly larger than that of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst (Fig. 9(A)). However, when Ni-loading amount was larger than 5wt%, CO conversion rate was lower than that of Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. Here, we discuss the effect of Ni substitution on CO conversion rate in more detail. Assuming that Co(x)–Ni(y)/Al2O3 catalyst is simple mixtures of the 100x/(x+y) percent of Co(20)/Al2O3 and the 100y/(x+y) percent of Ni(20)/Al2O3, CO conversion rate over Co(x)–Ni(y)/Al2O3 catalyst should theoretically consist with the solid line shown in Fig. 9(A). CO conversion rate over Co(19)+Ni(1)/Al2O3, Co(19)/Ni(1)/Al2O3, Ni(1)/Co(19)/Al2O3 and Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3 was higher than theoretical values, indicating that co-loading of Co and Ni had positive effect on the activity. In contrast, CO conversion rate over other catalysts, i.e., two kinds of Co(15)–Ni(5)/Al2O3 and three kinds of Co(10)–Ni(10)/Al2O3 catalysts, was lower than theoretical values, These results clearly show that co-loading of Co and Ni had negative effect on the activity when Ni-loading amount was large. Selectivity of CH4 and C2–C4 monotonically increased but that of C5+ products decreased with increasing Ni-loading amount (Table 2 and Fig. 9(B)). TOF also decreased with increasing Ni-loading amount (Fig. 9(C)). Influence of impregnation sequences on CO conversion, product selectivity and TOF was small, when Ni-loading amount was 1wt%. However, impregnation sequences largely influenced the catalytic activity, when Ni-loading amount was 5wt%. In other words, Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalyst showed much higher CO conversion rate, C5+ selectivity and TOF than Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3 and Ni(5)/Co(15)/Al2O3 catalysts. The fact that Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalysts showed low activity is interesting, since reduction degree and dispersion of Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalyst was the highest among three series of catalysts (Fig. 4(B) and C)). This indicates that factors other than the reduction degree and dispersion may determine the overall activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst. In the preparation of Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalyst, Ni was deposited first followed by Co. In contrast, Ni and Co were simultaneously deposited over Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalyst. In the preparation of Ni(5)/Co(15)/Al2O3 catalyst, Ni was deposited after Co-loading. Therefore, we suggest that high overall activity of Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalyst may be attributed to the high surface concentration of Co metal species. In contrast, low activity of Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3 and Ni(5)/Co(15)/Al2O3 catalysts is probably due to the high surface concentration of Ni metal species. We tentatively propose that core-shell particles with Ni core and Co shell might be effective to obtain the high catalytic activity. Then, activities of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared using different impregnation solutions were compared. As in the case of Fig. 9, CO conversion rate, C5+ selectivity and TOF over Co+Ni/Al2O3-N and Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts tended to decrease with increasing Ni-loading amount, although low (1wt%) Ni-loading slightly increased CO conversion rate (Fig 10 ). When catalysts with the same Co/Ni ratio was compared, CO conversion rate and TOF decreased in the order of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A>Co+Ni/Al2O3-N>Co+Ni/Al2O3 (Fig. 10(A) and (C)). C5+ selectivity decreased in the order of Co+Ni/Al2O3 >Co+Ni/Al2O3-A>Co+Ni/Al2O3-N (Fig. 10(B)). The variation of C5+ selectivity with the kind of impregnation solution was small, when Ni-loading amount was 0–5wt%. However, when Ni-loading amount was 10–20wt%, impregnation solution largely influenced the product selectivity. Among the examined samples, the highest activity was obtained over Co(19)+Ni(1)/Al2O3-A catalyst, which showed 1.6 times higher CO conversion rate than Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method. Effect of impregnation sequence on the catalytic activity was investigated for Co(15)–Ni(5)/Al2O3-A catalyst. Compared with Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3-A, Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3-A showed higher C5+ selectivity and lower CH4 selectivity (Table 2, entry 22). CO conversion rate over Co(15)/Ni(5)/Al2O3-A was comparable to that over Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3-A. In contrast, CO conversion rate over Ni(5)/Co(15)/Al2O3-A was lower than that over Co(15)+Ni(5)/Al2O3-A, although product selectivity was very similar to each other (Table 2, entry 23). These results were similar with the case of Co(15)–Ni(5)/Al2O3 catalysts prepared using pure water. Therefore, it is suggested that impregnation of first Ni and then Co would be preferable to the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons. Correlation between the structure of active sites and the catalytic activity was discussed. The order of CO conversion rate (Co+Ni/Al2O3-A>Co+Ni/Al2O3-N>Co+Ni/Al2O3) was not consistent with the order of reduction degree and dispersion (Co+Ni/Al2O3 >Co+Ni/Al2O3-N>Co+Ni/Al2O3-A). In other words, Co+Ni/Al2O3-A showed the highest CO conversion rate, although this catalyst showed the lowest reduction degree and dispersion. Therefore, we suggest that factors other than the reduction degree and the number of surface metal sites would determine the whole reaction rate. As shown in Fig. 10(A), CO conversion rate of catalysts containing Co was largely varied with the kind of impregnation solution, but that of catalysts containing Ni only was not. This fact indicates that the kind of impregnation solution would mainly influence the structure of Co. FT-IR spectroscopy coupled with the adsorption of CO molecules has been frequently used to study the nature of surface sites of various transition metal catalysts. This is because spectral characteristics of CO molecule strongly depend on the electronic state of adsorption sites [3,55]. Fig. 11 shows FT-IR spectra of adsorbed CO on Co(20)/Al2O3, Co(20)/Al2O3-N and Co(20)/Al2O3-A catalysts at room temperature. It is generally accepted that bands at 1990–2070cm−1 are assigned to the linearly bonded CO species with Co metal sites and those at 1800–1950cm−1 are assigned to the bridged adsorbed CO species on Co metal sites [3,10,26,34,55]. As shown in Fig. 11, linearly adsorbed CO band was observed largely from the spectra of all catalysts. On the other hand, bridged adsorbed CO bands were very small for all samples. The position and intensity of CO bands were varied with the kind of impregnation solution. Among the examined samples, intensity of linear-type CO band was highest over Co(20)/Al2O3-A catalyst and lowest over Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst. The order of intensity of linear-type CO band (Co+Ni/Al2O3-A> Co+Ni/Al2O3-N>Co+Ni/Al2O3) was consistent with that of CO conversion rate, indicating that high activity of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst would be due to the large amount of CO adsorption. Furthermore, linear-type CO band of Co(20)/Al2O3-A catalyst shifted to higher wavenumber than that of Co(20)/Al2O3 and Co(20)/Al2O3-N catalysts. The bonding mechanism between CO molecule and Co metal is generally explained as follows [3,55]. CO adsorption on the surface of Co metal sites proceeds via the C atom. The bonding between CO molecule and Co metal is induced by electron transfer from the CO(5σ) orbital into the empty bands of the metal (σ donation) and electron transfer from the occupied bands of the metal into CO(2π*) orbitals (π back-donation). When electron density of Co metal is high, back donation from the metal d orbitals into 2π* orbital of CO molecule increases and the CO bond weakens, leading to the lower CO stretching frequency. In contrast, when electron density of Co metal becomes lower, the back-donation into the 2π* orbital of CO molecule decreases and the CO bond becomes stronger, leading to the higher CO stretching frequency. From these theories, the present results indicate that electron density of surface Co metal sites on Co(20)/Al2O3-A catalyst would be lower than that of Co on Co(20)/Al2O3 and Co(20)/Al2O3-N catalysts. Therefore, we suggest that over the Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalysts, lowering of electron density of surface Co metal sites may decrease the hydrogenation rate and accelerate the formation of long-chain hydrocarbons. Results of FT-IR study clearly show that kinds of impregnation solution largely influence the CO adsorption amount and the electric density of surface Co metal sites. The overall activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst is determined by the number of active sites and the TOF. Reduction degree and dispersion of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst were lower than those of Co+Ni/Al2O3 and Co+Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts, indicating small number of active sites over Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst. However, TOF of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst was much higher than that of Co+Ni/Al2O3 and Co+Ni/Al2O3-N catalysts. High TOF of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst would be attributed to the large adsorption amount of CO molecules and/or low electron density of surface Co metal sites, as confirmed by FT-IR study. Since the positive effect of increase in TOF was larger than the negative effect of decrease in metal dispersion, Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst showed high overall activity for FT synthesis. 4 Conclusions The effect of Ni substitution on the structure and activity of Co/Al2O3 catalyst was studied in order to prepare highly active and inexpensive Co catalysts for FT synthesis. Bimetallic Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. Influence of the Co/Ni ratio, impregnation sequences and solutions was investigated in detail. Loading small amount of Ni slightly increased CO conversion rate at nearly constant C5+ selectivity, but excess Ni-loading largely decreased CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity. Impregnation sequence had small influence on the catalytic activity, when Ni-loading amount was low. However, when Ni-loading amount was high, catalysts prepared by sequential impregnation method (Ni first and then Co) exhibited better catalytic performance than those prepared by co-impregnation method and reverse sequential impregnation method (Co first and then Ni). These results indicate that catalysts with Co-rich surface would be superior to those with Ni-rich surface. The activity of Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts also depended on the kind of impregnation solution. Co+Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared using aqueous NH3 solution (Co+Ni/Al2O3-A) showed higher activity than those prepared using pure water or aqueous HNO3 solution. The best catalyst was Co(19)+Ni(1)/Al2O3-A. CO conversion rate over this catalyst was 1.6 times as high as that over Co(20)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method. High activity of Co+Ni/Al2O3-A catalyst would be attributed to the large amount of CO adsorption and/or the low electron density of surface Co metal species. coredata.dc:description: The effect of Ni substitution on the Fischer–Tropsch (FT) synthesis activity and selectivity of alumina supported cobalt (Co/Al2O3) catalyst was investigated with a continuous stirred tank reactor at 230°C and 1MPa. Bimetallic Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts were prepared by an impregnation method. Total amount of supported metal was fixed at 20wt%. Influence of the Co/Ni ratio, impregnation sequences and solutions on the structure and activity of Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalyst was systematically studied. Low Ni-loading slightly increased CO conversion rate at nearly constant C5+ selectivity, but excess Ni-loading largely decreased CO conversion rate and C5+ selectivity. The catalytic activity did not depend on impregnation sequence, when Ni-loading amount was low. However, when Co was substituted with large amount of Ni, catalysts prepared by sequential impregnation method (Ni first and then Co) showed higher activity than those prepared by co-impregnation method and reverse sequential impregnation method (Co first and then Ni). These results indicate that catalysts with a Co-rich surface would be better than those with a Ni-rich surface. Impregnation solution also influenced the catalytic activity. Co–Ni/Al2O3 catalysts prepared by co-impregnation method using aqueous NH3 solution (Co+Ni/Al2O3-A) showed higher activity than those prepared using pure water or aqueous HNO3 solution. The best catalyst was Co(19wt%)+Ni(1wt%)/Al2O3-A, which exhibited 1.6 times as high activity as Co(20wt%)/Al2O3 catalyst prepared by a conventional impregnation method. The variation of catalytic activity with the kind of impregnation solution would be attributed to the differences in CO adsorption amount and/or electron density of surface Co metal sites.
coredata.dc:title: Fischer–Tropsch synthesis over alumina supported bimetallic Co–Ni catalyst: Effect of impregnation sequence and solution
